Stories like this are true. I had grad school classmates from central Asia 
whose wives married them at 14 and 16 years old, all arranged marriages. 
Fortunately my friends were decent husbands and their married lives were 
tolerable, but there were clearly some issues. The wives were just too 
young and too uneducated to be calm, rational thinking caretakers for their 
families. 

Bride kidnappings are also true. In a lot of traditional societies the men 
pays an amount of money to the women's family to marry the girl. But in 
cases where they can't afford a bride, they would kidnap a girl, keep her 
overnight, and she is no longer considered "pure" and has to marry the guy 
to keep from being shamed.

comments.text:
+yahtoray3
Well, in some cases, both parties are young. In many cases in the Southern 
US, both the groom and the bride were fairly close in age, but the groom 
was forced into marriage in a "shotgun" wedding to avoid prosecution for 
violating the statutes. Sometimes, there were mistakes in age and the groom 
was tricked into believing the partner was older than she really was. (As a 
side note: today, most states don't even allow the shotgun wedding defense, 
but there are many 17 year-olds who are forced to a lifetime punishment 
with the sex-offender restrictions for consensual sex with a 15 year old. 
There are also occasionally legitimate mistakes in age where the law 
demands the perpetrator to be treated as a child predator.)

Usually, the fact that men can do their part in the reproductive process in 
old age, albeit often with some difficulty, while women cannot because of 
menopause, has exerted evolutionary pressures on men to generally pursue 
moneymaking/education and marry at an older age. Generally, the more 
polygamy and child marriages, the higher the birthrate. The more education 
women have, the lower the birthrate in society. Some of this might be due 
to more knowledge of birth control, but it's mainly due to the fact that 
women marry later because they're too busy studying. 

Also, it might have boosted life-expectancy. In a primitive society, if a 
13 year old girl were to marry a 13 year old boy, there would be a good 
chance that the 13 year old boy carried genes that lowered life-expectancy 
and could pass these on to offspring. However, if a 13 year old girl were 
to marry a 50 year old man, the odds of the groom passing on relatively 
strong longevity genes to offspring would increase dramatically. Due to 
menopause preventing procreation, it wouldn't be advantageous to have young 
boys marry older women. 

There was one society in the US that forced young boys to be child 
grooms(in a sort of swinger community) to older women before 
age-of-consents applied to males. It was called the Oneida Community, and 
one of its traumatized members assassinated President Garfield. Guess what 
happened. Its members had a low birthrate and died out! It's now just a 
regular silverware company or brand.
